sentence: Businesses that use Visa to process some types of transactions may be facing new fees.
The move could help fuel gains in revenue for Visa, according to Susquehanna Financial.
PayPal Holdings ’ (ticker: PYPL) revenue trends are also looking impressive and could result in the company lifting guidance when it reports third-quarter earnings, according to Wolfe Research.
Analysts at both firms reiterated positive views on the stocks on Thursday.
But there are caveats: The stocks trade at lofty valuations, and gains are likely to be muted from here.
Visa (V) seems to be flexing its pricing muscle in the business-to-business (B2B) “virtual card” market.
The company recently issued a bulletin saying it would impose a new “B2B virtual payment service fee” of 0.60% on domestic transactions and 1.55% on cross-border transactions.
Susquehanna analyst James Friedman estimates that the new fees could lift Visa’s revenue 2% to 4% above current estimates, starting in 2022.
“It’s a large fee for the card networks,” he said in an interview, noting that Mastercard (MA) charges similar fees.
Friedman maintained the equivalent of a Buy rating on Visa, though he trimmed 2020 and 2021 earnings estimates to reflect ongoing weakness in consumer and cross-border transactions.
He kept his price target intact at $225, implying 12.5% gains from recent prices around $200.
Barron’s recently wrote favorably about the card networks and PayPal, noting that they are benefiting from stay-at-home trends and a shift to e-commerce during the pandemic.
Other digital-payment stocks that stand to benefit include Square (SQ), Global Payments (GPN), and Fidelity National Information Services (FIS).
Virtual B2B payments are a large and growing market for the card networks, worth $320 billion in annual transaction volume.
Accenture estimates the U.S. virtual B2B market is growing at twice the rate of consumer card volumes and will reach $553 billion in volume by 2024.
Virtual cards are used for B2B transactions between employees and merchants.
A driver for a utility company, for example, would use a prepaid card to buy gas, but the card couldn’t be used to purchase other items.
Virtual cards are also used for freelance or gig-economy payments: An Uber Eats driver, for instance, would pay a restaurant with a virtual card.
And virtual B2B is used extensively for online travel.
Friedman writes that virtual cards, increasingly used by businesses to control spending, improve reporting, and reduce fraud, may be reaching an adoption tipping point.
Visa’s pitch in raising fees is that it’s adding value for merchants and is aiming to price the service accordingly, Friedman says.
He estimates that Visa now has 25% to 50% of U.S. virtual card volumes.
Tacking on a 0.60% fee could boost revenue by $480 million to $960 million annually.
Mastercard captures more of the virtual B2B market, and it charges less in some respects.
Mastercard’s fee average is 0.85%, versus a range of 0.60% to 1.55% for Visa, according to Friedman.
With Visa now raising prices, Mastercard may be tempted to follow suit—or to maintain a price advantage with merchants and increase its market share.
PayPal is also looking more attractive, according to Wolfe Research analyst Darrin Peller.
He maintained an Outperform rating and $225 price target on the stock.
But he now expects PayPal to lift guidance when it reports third-quarter earnings on Nov. 2.
Peller notes that PayPal will face a revenue headwind next year when an operating agreement with eBay (EBAY) expires.
He estimates that eBay comprised 7% of PayPal’s transaction volumes in the second quarter of 2020, and that losing the contract will shave 3% to 4% off PayPal’s 2021 revenue.
But the company’s tailwinds should be more than enough to offset those losses.
Among them are gains at PayPal’s Venmo unit, new point-of-sale transactions at bricks-and-mortar retail, and international partnerships.

“Overall, we expect a 3Q beat,” Peller writes, “coupled with a sound 2021 initial guide will be enough to satisfy investors, even with shares at highs.”

One hitch to both stocks is valuation.
Visa trades at 33 times 2021 earnings while PayPal goes for 45 times.
Those are steep premiums to market multiples and may cap the stocks’ gains, even if the underlying business trends continue to improve.
Visa stock was down 1.5%, at $199.21, in recent trading, while PayPal was down 1.6%, at $200.33, and Mastercard was down 2%, at $335.73.
The S&P 500 was down 0.7%
